title.narrative: Research for Health in Humanitarian Crises 2020-2025

description.narrative: The R2HC is a globally recognised research programme focuses on maximising the potential for public health research to bring about positive change in humanitarian response and helps inform decision making in humanitarian response.
To improve health outcomes by strengthening the evidence base for public health interventions in humanitarian crises.

title.narrative: Knowledge and learning from R2HC funded research is captured, synthesised and shared through communications and engagement activities
3.1 # of communications products/ publications generated from grantees research outputs for stakeholder community by R2HC or in collaboration with others
Collaborative research partnerships funded and supported to generate high quality ethical research addressing priority health evidence gaps and to achieve uptake of findings
2.1 # Calls launched and studies funded addressing clear needs/gaps in priority areas.

comment.narrative: X Calls (by type: Annual, Thematic, Responsive); X Seed funding grants; X Studies funded (by type: Annual, Thematic, Responsive).
2 Calls launched: 1 Responsive Call (COVID-19), 1 Annual Call (Call 8); 24 Seed Fund grants (Call 7); 23 studies funded: 15 Responsive (COVID-19) studies, 8 Annual studies funded (Call 7)

title.narrative: Collaborative research partnerships funded and supported to generate high quality ethical research addressing priority health evidence gaps and to achieve uptake of findings
2.6 # and type of non-financial activities to support grantees during research implementation

comment.narrative: 1 kick off meeting per call; At least 1 facilitated peer learning event; At least 1 partnership workshop; At least 1 convened teleconference/event for grantees
2 Kick off meetings held; 3 COVID-19 cohort support meetings held; 2 templates developed to support study team's communications

title.narrative: Collaborative research partnerships funded and supported to generate high quality ethical research addressing priority health evidence gaps and to achieve uptake of findings
2.2 Number of studies recommended for funding by the Funding Committee (per call);

comment.narrative: At least 7 studies recommended for funding per annual call

title.narrative: Public health researchers using R2HC evidence-based guidance on conducting research in humanitarian contexts to inform design and implementation of quality studies
B.2 # researchers reporting value of participation in R2HC convened events

comment.narrative: Ave 80% R2HC COVID-19 grants represented in voluntary R2HC-convened monthly CoP calls, with up to 23 participants in each (PROXY for researcher satisfaction)

title.narrative: Collaborative research partnerships funded and supported to generate high quality ethical research addressing priority health evidence gaps and to achieve uptake of findings
2.4 % of funded studies in the ACAPS category of crisis severity at time of award: Very High Severity; High Severity; Medium Severity

comment.narrative: % of funded studies in the ACAPS category of crisis severity at time of award: Very High Severity (at least 10%), High Severity (at least 30%), Medium Severity
Call 7: Very High Severity: 10%, High Severity: 40, Medium Severity: 20% COVID19 Call: Very High Severity: 11%, High Severity: 32%, Medium Severity: 58%

title.narrative: Collaborative research partnerships funded and supported to generate high quality ethical research addressing priority health evidence gaps and to achieve uptake of findings
2.3 # and type of institutions awarded grants (academic , iNGO, Government) and # and type (research institution (North/South), NGO, UN Agency, Government, Other) of partners within a research team

comment.narrative: Lead agencies (new grants awarded): 15 academic (3 LMIC); 7 (I)NGO (1 LMIC); 0 Govt; 1 UN Agency Other partners within research teams: 29 academic (17 LMIC); 30 (I)NGO (15 LMIC); 4 Govt; 8 UN Agency Mean: 4.1 total partners per grant

title.narrative: Public health researchers using R2HC evidence-based guidance on conducting research in humanitarian contexts to inform design and implementation of quality studies

B.1 # researchers reporting use of publications/guidance/case studies generated through R2HC by topic (e.g. Humanitarian Health Evidence Review (HHER), GBV Methodologies Guidance, Research Ethics Tool (including working with people affected by crisis)

comment.narrative: New reporting templates not yet in use.

title.narrative: Key humanitarian stakeholders have access to and are informed of key new evidence, through strategic engagement and communications
4.4 Engagement metrics generated through our Website and Social media.

comment.narrative: The Humanitarian Health Evidence Review: 1,285 pageviews & 194 downloads (plus 107 downloads of executive summary) Mitigating Operational Challenges in Humanitarian Health Research (published February 2020): 601 pageviews & 113 downloads Research Methodologies in Humanitarian Crises Review (published in February 2020): 1,035 pageviews & 249 downloads Research Ethics Tool: 2,057 pageviews & 343 downloads Research portfolio 2019: 261 pageviews & 76 downloads Research snapshots ( a collective total for all): 79 pageviews & 217 downloads

title.narrative: Public health researchers using R2HC evidence-based guidance on conducting research in humanitarian contexts to inform design and implementation of quality studies
B.3 # of citations of R2HC developed guidance
Key humanitarian stakeholders have access to and are informed of key new evidence, through strategic engagement and communications
4.1 R2HC strategic engagement plan delivered (with objectives, targets and key events/milestones for engagement identified)

comment.narrative: Key activities with priority staekhodlers delivered in 2024. Evaluate success of Phase 4 engagement. Develop onward engagement plans
Strategic engagement plan in place. Activities delivered as planned with 2020 in-person activities adjusted to be on-line due to Covid-19, where feasible.

title.narrative: Evidence from R2HC funded research positively influences the public health policies and practices of key humanitarian actors
1.1 # key humanitarian stakeholders reporting shifts in organisational policy and/or practice (with description)

2.7 # of (annual call) grantees that have developed a stakeholder engagement strategy

comment.narrative: 1 RIT Workshop or Online Course completed per grantee, 1 SES developed per grantee
Members of 9 study teams registered for online course and partially completed. Anticipating 5-6 SES completed by end of year (many teams uptake planning disrupted due to pandemic).

title.narrative: Evidence from R2HC funded research positively influences the public health policies and practices of key humanitarian actors

Policy and programming of humanitarian operational and policy actors is evidence-based
